title: Arie Haan
text:
Arend "Arie" Haan (; born 16 November 1948) is a Dutch <a href="Association%20football">football</a> manager and former player who played as a <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a>. He scored 6 goals in 35 matches for the <a href="Netherlands%20national%20football%20team">Dutch national team</a> of the 1970s. At club level, he enjoyed a successful career with <a href="AFC%20Ajax">AFC Ajax</a>, <a href="R.S.C.%20Anderlecht">R.S.C. Anderlecht</a>, <a href="Standard%20Li%C3%A8ge">Standard Liège</a> and <a href="PSV%20Eindhoven">PSV Eindhoven</a>.
He participated in seven finals of European club competitions with five victories and two defeats. He was also known for his goals from long distance. At international level, he played 35 times for the Dutch national team and was on the losing side for them in two World Cup finals.
After retiring as a player, he managed numerous club sides in Europe and China, as well as the national teams of China, Cameroon and Albania.
Playing career.
Haan joined AFC Ajax in 1969 and was a member of Ajax that won the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">European Cup</a> for three consecutive years, from <a href="European%20Cup%201970-71">1971</a> until <a href="European%20Cup%201972-73">1973</a>, the <a href="Intercontinental%20Cup%20%28football%29">Intercontinental Cup</a> in 1972 and two <a href="European%20Super%20Cup">European Super Cup</a>s, in 1972 and 1973. Also with Ajax, he won three <a href="Eredivisie">Eredivisie</a> titles in <a href="1969%E2%80%9370%20Eredivisie">1969–70</a>, <a href="1971%E2%80%9372%20Eredivisie">1971–72</a> and <a href="1972%E2%80%9373%20Eredivisie">1972–73</a> and the <a href="KNVB%20Cup">Dutch Cup</a> from 1970 until 1972. In 1970, his team won <a href="Double%20%28association%20football%29">the Double</a> and in 1972, <a href="the%20Treble">the Treble</a>.
He joined Belgian club <a href="R.S.C.%20Anderlecht">R.S.C. Anderlecht</a> in 1975 and was a member of the club's greatest ever successful period, when they won two <a href="European%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup">European Cup Winners' Cup</a>s in <a href="UEFA%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup%201975-76">1976</a> and <a href="UEFA%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup%201977-78">1978</a>. Those two seasons, he won two more <a href="European%20Super%20Cup">European Super Cup</a>s (the previous two were with Ajax). The club again reached the final of that Cup Winners' Cup in <a href="UEFA%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup%201976-77">1977</a> too, but they were beaten by <a href="Hamburger%20SV">Hamburger SV</a>. Also with Anderlecht he won the <a href="Belgian%20Cup">Belgian Cup</a> in 1975–76 and the <a href="Belgian%20First%20Division%20A">Belgian Championship</a> in 1980–81.
After winning the championship with Anderlecht, he played for Standard Liège for two seasons, when the club won two championships. also the <a href="Belgian%20Supercup">Belgian Supercup</a> in 1981.
In 1982, the club achieved its greatest success, when they reached their first (and to date the only) Cup Winners' Cup final, when they were beaten at <a href="Camp%20Nou">Camp Nou</a> by <a href="FC%20Barcelona">FC Barcelona</a>. That year they also won the only double in their history. Returning to his country in 1983, he played one season for <a href="PSV%20Eindhoven">PSV</a>. Haan finished his career for Hong Kong champions <a href="Seiko%20SA">Seiko SA</a>.
He has 35 matches with his national team, scoring 6 goals. His most famous was a 40-yard strike in the Netherlands' match against <a href="Italy%20national%20squad">Italy</a> in the second group stage of the <a href="1978%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1978 FIFA World Cup</a>. His goal in the 2–2 game against West Germany, also a strike from far out in the field, helped the Dutch national team reach the final, where they were beaten by Argentina 3–1 in extra time. He also participated in the <a href="1974%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1974 FIFA World Cup</a> when Netherlands were beaten in the final by <a href="Germany%20national%20football%20team">West Germany</a> 2–1.
Managerial career.
Two months after retiring as a player, he became trainer of <a href="R.%20Antwerp%20F.C.">Antwerp</a>. However, in the middle of the 1985–86 season he became coach of <a href="R.%20S.%20C.%20Anderlecht">Anderlecht Brussels</a>, replacing <a href="Paul%20Van%20Himst">Paul Van Himst</a> who was fired from the club. <a href="Franky%20Vercauteren">Franky Vercauteren</a> and <a href="Morten%20Olsen">Morten Olsen</a> featured in his team alongside players like goalkeeper <a href="Jacky%20Munaron">Jacky Munaron</a>, <a href="Luka%20Peruzovi%C4%87">Luka Peruzović</a>, <a href="Erwin%20Vandenbergh">Erwin Vandenbergh</a>, <a href="Alexandre%20Czerniatynski">Alex Czerniatynski</a>, <a href="Enzo%20Scifo">Enzo Scifo</a> and <a href="Georges%20Gr%C3%BCn">Georges Grün</a>. In 1986, Anderlecht won the championship, after a two-legged play-off against <a href="Club%20Brugge">Club Brugge</a>. Club Brugge forced a 1–1 draw away to Anderlecht, and led 2–0 at home after thirty minutes, but Anderlecht managed to equalise. The same season, the club reached the semi finals of the European Champions' Cup, by eliminating <a href="Bayern%20Munich">Bayern Munich</a>. The following season, his team retained the Belgian Championship.
After <a href="Belgium">Belgium</a> he became trainer of <a href="VfB%20Stuttgart">VfB Stuttgart</a> in Germany on 1 July 1987. Stuttgart reached their first European cup final in <a href="UEFA%20Cup%201988-89">1989</a>, the <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a>, but failed to win the trophy against <a href="SSC%20Napoli">SSC Napoli</a> (1–2, 3–3), a team that <a href="Diego%20Maradona">Diego Maradona</a> was playing for at the time. He remained in Stuttgart until 26 March 1990. In July 1990 he became manager of <a href="1.%20FC%20N%C3%BCrnberg">1. FC Nürnberg</a> where he remained for a single season.
Returning to Belgium in 1991, he coached Standard Liège until the middle of the season <a href="1993%E2%80%9394%20Belgian%20First%20Division">1993–94</a> and won the Belgian Cup in 1993. In the <a href="1994%E2%80%9395%20in%20Greek%20football">1994–95</a> season he was appointed coach of <a href="PAOK%20FC">PAOK FC</a> and he remained there until October 1995, after which he returned to the Netherlands and managed <a href="Feyenoord">Feyenoord</a> for two seasons. In his first season Feyenoord finished 2nd in the <a href="Eredivisie">Eredivisie</a>.
After ten years, in December 1997, Haan enjoyed a further stint at Anderlecht, spending nine months at the club before returning to PAOK, where he remained as coach until December 1999. He went to <a href="Cyprus">Cyprus</a>, to become <a href="AC%20Omonia">AC Omonia</a> manager in November 2000 but he coached the team only for two matches since he had a great offer from <a href="Austria%20Vienna">Austria Vienna</a> to become the team's manager. He asked from his club to release his contract and that was accepted. He left from Austria in August 2001.
He coached the <a href="China%20national%20football%20team">Chinese national football team</a> for two years since December 2002. In 2004, <a href="China%20PR">China</a> hosted the <a href="AFC%20Asian%20Cup">Asia Cup</a> and reached the final where his team was beaten by <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan</a>. However, his team did not qualify for the <a href="2006%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2006 FIFA World Cup</a> after their elimination from the <a href="2006%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28AFC%29">First round of qualifications</a>, where China lost the first position the group to <a href="Kuwait%20national%20football%20team">Kuwait</a>. He remained as coach of China until November 2004.
Moving to <a href="Persepolis%20F.C.">Persepolis F.C.</a> in February 2006, he helped his team reach the <a href="Hazfi%20Cup">Hazfi Cup</a> final. He was fired by the club just before the <a href="IPL%202006/07">2006–07</a> season began as he had problems with club management. Recently, he became trainer of <a href="Cameroon%20national%20football%20team">Cameroon national team</a>, however he resigned less than six months into a two-year contract citing interference from the president of Cameroon Football Federation Mohammed Iya as the reason.
In December 2007, Albanian Football Federation president Armando Duka announced Haan would replace Croatia's <a href="Otto%20Baric">Otto Baric</a> as <a href="Albania%20national%20football%20team">Albania</a> head coach. He signed a two-year contract on 4 January 2008 and cancelled his contract on 15 April 2009.
On 29 May 2009 it was confirmed that Haan will succeed <a href="Wei%20Xin">Wei Xin</a> as the new manager of struggling <a href="Chinese%20Super%20League">Chinese Super League</a> side <a href="Chongqing%20Lifan%20F.C.">Chongqing Lifan</a> and took over in June that year. In August 2009, Haan was suspended for three Super League matches after waving money at a referee. Chongqing Lifan were relegated at the end of the 2009 league season and Haan left for fellow Chinese Super League team <a href="Tianjin%20Teda%20F.C.">Tianjin Teda F.C.</a>. He brought the team to the second place in 2010 season, the club's highest rank ever achieved in the China Super League, which earned the team a place in the AFC Champions League in 2011. In the 2011 season of CSL, though the team only ranked 10th. at last, Haan led the team won the championship of China's FA Cup, with the score of 2–1 against <a href="Shandong%20Luneng%20Taishan%20F.C.">Shandong Luneng Taishan F.C.</a>. This championship is the first title Tianjin Teda achieved since its establishment in 1998.
